text.p: Copper prices tumbled in jittery trading on Thursday in a market anxiously pondering a report that a big volume of the metal may be hidden in European warehouses.
In Chicago, the Commodities Research Bureau index gained 0.95 points to 242.33.

Copper ended off lows but weaker at $2,031 per tonne, after surging to 2-1/2 month highs at $2,083 on Wedensday. Many traders and analysts dismissed as highly unlikely a report issued on Wednesday that estimated that nearly 600,000 tonnes of copper not previously reported had built up in Dutch bonded warehouses.

In other commodities markets, gold drifted slightly lower after posting healthy gains earlier this week. Bullion finished in London at $382.50 an ounce, down from $384.05 on Wednesday. But dealers said they were looking for it to continue pushing higher in the near term after coming off lows around $377 an ounce earlier this month.

An early cold snap was reigniting a blistering oil price rally as oil companies rushed to replenish low heating fuel stocks before demand in the northern hemisphere took hold. World benchmark Brent crude oil futures stood at around $23.80 per barrel late in the London afternoon, just over a dollar below October's six-year high of $25.06 and well above an early-November low of $22.11. Many oil traders said they believed that prices will return to six-year highs of $25 per barrel within the next six weeks.
Wheat prices in Chicago held their three-week highs from Wednesday at around $4.00 per bushel, achieved on bullish export prospects.
Last trades or bids for key Australian-interest commodities. Previous close in brackets.
Copper Grade A (LME cash official US$/tonne 2090 ( 2131)
Zinc High Grade (LME cash official US$/tonn 1038 ( 1041)
